items.author: The Hollywood Reporter
items.content: To Kill A Mockingbird is a product of American realism, and it is a rare and worthy treasure.

items.author: William Thomas
items.content: Storytelling doesn't get much better than this.

items.author: Variety
items.content: To Kill a Mockingbird is a major film achievement, a significant, captivating and memorable picture that ranks with the best of recent years.

items.author: Marc Lee
items.content: As Mulligan so deftly demonstrates, the story is in the characters, their failings and fragility, their heroism and nobility of spirit. It's in the depiction of heart-breaking cruelty and heart-warming humanity. It's in the innocence of a child's world overshadowed by the evil that adults do.

items.author: Time
items.content: One of the year's most fetching and affecting pictures.

items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: To Kill a Mockingbird is a faithful adaptation of one of the 20th century's most important American works of literature. It is also a masterpiece in its own right. This is one of those rare productions where everything is in place - a superior script, a perfect cast, and a director who has a clear vision and achieves what he sets out to do.

items.author: Boston Globe
items.content: There is not only artistry in the development of the story - there is beauty, sympathy and emotional appeal in almost every scene.

items.author: Bosley Crowther
items.content: Their charming enactments of a father and his children in that close relationship that can occur at only one brief period are worth all the footage of the film.

items.author: TV Guide Magazine
items.content: A hauntingly nostalgic portrayal of childhood mischief set in a racially divided Alabama town in the 1930s. If the film's tone sometimes seems overly righteous, it's offset by a poetic lyricism that is difficult to resist embracing.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: To Kill a Mockingbird, set in Maycomb, Alabama, in 1932, uses the realities of its time only as a backdrop for the portrait of a brave white liberal.
